Thanks for the insights Mike. I agree that in theory adding fundamental 
data into the mix is a good idea.
Unfortunateley I haven't found a way of getting good historic data for 
those parameters which means
I can't really train a net adequately using them. I have daily 
open,high,low,close & volume data for about
17,000 stocks, some with data sets going back to 1962 so that's what I'm 
going to use as my inputs
(suitably processed & normalised of course).
I'm a great believer in the efficient market hypothesis. Bizarrely, even 
a few days before Sept. 11th there
was a rush to buy short positions in the futures market. Especially on 
Airplane Operator stocks!
Obviously the conspiracy theorists among us will have their own ideas on 
this, but my view is that sometimes
small movements (caused by rumour or a modicum of insider dealing) will 
trigger some more people t
o jump on the bandwagon (especially the banks and the pension funds) and 
you get positive feedback
cycles kicking up which will take the price a fair bit lower or higher.  
I'm trying to see if it's possible to
train a net to recognise when such things are on the cards.

Emyr
